column1: Shelbyville is a city in Bedford County
column2: Tennessee

column5: the county seat of Bedford County
column6: was laid out in 1810 and incorporated in 1819. The town is a hub of the Tennessee Walking Horse industry and has been nicknamed "The Walking Horse Capital of the World".

column2: which flows around the southern and eastern sides of town.According to the United States Census Bureau

column1: Shelbyville is known as "The Pencil City" because of its historical importance as a center of wood-cased pencil manufacturing. It is still a site for manufacture of writing instruments. In 1982
column2: National Pen Corporation purchased its largest competitor
column3: U.S. Pencil and Stationery Company. Sanford Corporation produces the Sharpie
column5: in the city. It was in Shelbyville in 1991 that the world's longest pencil was produced
column8: weighing 27 pounds (12 kg).Other major business operations in Shelbyville include manufacturers Calsonic Kansei
column11: and Jostens; it is also home to a Tyson Foods facility and a distribution center for Wal-Mart
column12: as well as several nationwide trucking businesses.

column1: Shelbyville is at the intersection of U.S. Route 231 and U.S. Route 41A. It was the terminus of a branch line (from Wartrace)
column2: located along what is now known as Railroad Avenue
column3: connecting with what was once known as the Saint Louis

column1: The Tennessee Walking Horse National Celebration takes place each year during the 11 days and nights prior to Labor Day. It is the largest show for the Tennessee Walking Horse
column2: during which the breed's World Grand Champion and over 20 World Champions are named. The Celebration is a festival event where more than $650
column3: 000 in prizes and awards are given. The Celebration began in 1939
column4: and the first winner was Strolling Jim.

column1: Bedford County School District operates primary and secondary schools. Shelbyville Central High School is the local public high school.

After the end of non-penal slavery in the United States the AME Church opened a school for African-American children. The public school system graduated its first black class in 1890. The schools for African-American children operated by the district were East Bedford School and Bedford County Training School for Negroes (a.k.a. John McAdams High School and also Harris High School for Negroes). Schools racially integrated after 1964.
The Tennessee College of Applied Technology - Shelbyville is one of 46 institutions in the Tennessee Board of Regents System
column2: the seventh largest system of higher education in the nation. This system comprises six universities
column4: and twenty-six technology centers. More than 80 percent of all Tennessee students attending public institutions are enrolled in a Tennessee Board of Regents institution.

column1: Shelbyville has one news media outlet
column2: the Shelbyville Times-Gazette. It was also the former home of the Shelbyville Free Press.

column1: The Shelbyville Free Press was a digital news media outlet that offered the public a liberal voice and included a multi-platform model in communications including a website
column2: Facebook Page
column4: and a United States Press Agency Site.  The SFP was a free news outlet and charged no subscription or advertising fees to its readers. It is no longer active.The Shelbyville Times-Gazette is a traditional printed newspaper
column5: which is subscription-based and charges for advertisements.

column1: Shelbyville was featured in Miranda Lambert's video "Famous in a Small Town".The city was also profiled in the film Welcome to Shelbyville
column2: as part of the PBS documentary film series Independent Lens. The film spotlights recent demographic changes in the community
column3: with a focus on the growing number of immigrants from Latin America and Somalia (both Somalis and people from the Bantu minority ethnic group).

column1: Shelbyville was also featured in GADA film's Our Very Own (2005 Film)
column2: directed by Cameron Watson.  The film
column4: highlighted some of the peculiar and humorous memories of Shelbyville in the 1970s. The film follows five teenagers who are determined to meet Shelbyville's own Sondra Locke.  Filmed in 2004
